text: Apple continued expanding its renewable electricity program across its global operations, maintaining its commitment to run all facilities on 100% clean energy. The company also supported suppliers in transitioning to renewables, accelerating progress toward reducing supply-chain emissions.

Apple advanced low-carbon material design by increasing recycled aluminum, plastic, and rare earth elements in its products. The company focused on eliminating high-emission materials and redesigning components to reduce environmental impact from manufacturing.

Apple progressed toward its 2030 carbon-neutral goal by scaling energy efficiency programs with manufacturers, piloting low-carbon smelting technologies, and collaborating with facility partners to adopt clean energy procurement strategies.

Apple expanded water efficiency programs at major sites and worked with local stakeholders to protect watershed health. New initiatives included improved recycling systems and nature-based restoration projects to support long-term water resilience.

The company increased the number of facilities meeting its Zero Waste to Landfill standards by implementing waste-sorting programs, redesigning packaging streams, and expanding reuse and recycling of manufacturing materials.

Apple strengthened its circular economy model by increasing recovery of valuable materials through advanced disassembly robots and improving end-of-life recycling pathways. These efforts help limit reliance on newly mined resources.

Through the Supplier Clean Energy Program, Apple supported hundreds of partners in shifting to renewable electricity. The initiative contributed to significant avoided emissions across the company’s extended manufacturing footprint.

Apple continued investment in forestry, mangrove, and ecosystem restoration projects designed to increase carbon removal and protect biodiversity. These nature-based initiatives provide climate benefits while supporting local communities.

Amazon continued expanding its renewable energy portfolio, adding new wind and solar projects across multiple continents. The company remained on track to match 100% of its electricity use with renewable energy as it scales its global operations.

Amazon grew its fleet of electric delivery vehicles and invested in low-carbon fuels for long-haul logistics. These initiatives support Amazon’s long-term goal of reducing transportation emissions across its supply chain.

The company implemented new cooling technologies and optimized server utilization to increase energy efficiency across data centers. These steps help lower operational emissions while supporting expanding cloud workloads.

Amazon reduced single-use plastics in shipments across key regions and expanded its recyclable packaging offerings. Efforts included material redesign, supplier engagement, and investments in local recycling infrastructure.
Amazon strengthened water-efficiency strategies at data centers by implementing advanced cooling systems and supporting watershed restoration projects in high-stress regions worldwide.
The company increased investment in recycled and low-impact materials for private-label products, using Life Cycle Assessment tools to guide sustainable design across product categories.
Amazon supported community-focused climate resilience programs, including emergency response efforts, local energy projects, and partnerships that help communities adapt to climate impacts.

The company expanded nature-based climate projects, including forest conservation and restoration initiatives designed to generate long-term carbon benefits and protect biodiversity in critical ecosystems.
UHG advanced its climate strategy by improving energy efficiency in facilities, exploring clean-energy procurement options, and modernizing equipment to reduce emissions across operational sites.
The company expanded community investment programs focused on improving health outcomes, addressing social determinants of health, and supporting underserved populations through targeted initiatives.

UHG strengthened its preparedness and resiliency planning to ensure continuity of care during extreme weather events and public-health emergencies, integrating climate risk assessments into long-term planning.
The organization collaborated with suppliers to encourage environmentally responsible practices, expand transparency, and reduce environmental impacts within the health-care supply chain.
UHG implemented water-efficiency measures in high-use facilities and expanded recycling and waste diversion programs across administrative and clinical sites.
The company used digital health platforms to reduce travel-related emissions and improve efficiency through remote care, virtual services, and optimized clinical operations.
UHG expanded programs supporting employee wellbeing, training, diversity, and inclusion as part of a broader strategy to foster a resilient, engaged workforce.
UHG supported local organizations working on environmental health, air quality improvement, and sustainable community development to promote long-term wellbeing.
Chevron continued investing in carbon capture, biofuels, hydrogen, and other lower-carbon technologies aimed at reducing life-cycle emissions across the energy system.
The company advanced methane-reduction initiatives by deploying monitoring technologies, upgrading equipment, and strengthening leak-detection programs at operational sites.
Chevron expanded partnerships to scale renewable fuels and transportation solutions, supporting customers’ needs for lower-carbon energy options.
The company implemented new technologies to improve energy efficiency across upstream and downstream operations, helping reduce emissions intensity.
Chevron worked on managing water use in high-stress regions by improving recycling and treatment systems and collaborating with local stakeholders to support watershed resilience.
The company engaged in habitat restoration and conservation initiatives, integrating biodiversity considerations into land-use planning and remediation programs.
Chevron supported local economic development, education, and environmental initiatives in communities near its operations, prioritizing long-term partnerships.
The company expanded programs focused on worker safety, emergency preparedness, and mental-health support across its global workforce.
Citi advanced its sustainable finance goals by directing capital toward climate solutions, low-carbon infrastructure, and inclusive economic growth initiatives.
The bank continued refining its net-zero transition plan by assessing sector-level pathways, engaging clients on decarbonization strategies, and improving emissions transparency.
Citi integrated climate scenario analysis and risk assessments into business decision-making, considering physical and transition risks across global operations.
The bank expanded renewable-energy sourcing and implemented energy-efficiency upgrades across branches and offices to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions.
Citi supported programs to advance racial equity, financial inclusion, and community development, including small-business lending and affordable housing initiatives.
The company engaged suppliers on environmental reporting, responsible sourcing, and performance improvements aligned with Citi’s sustainability principles.
Citi expanded funding for climate resilience, supporting communities recovering from natural disasters and extreme weather impacts.
Citi strengthened human-rights due-diligence processes, focusing on transparency, worker protections, and responsible business practices.
NVIDIA advanced energy-efficient computing by designing chips and systems optimized for high performance with lower power consumption, reducing emissions intensity in AI and HPC workloads.
The company increased its renewable-energy procurement across operations and data centers, supporting long-term emissions reduction goals.
NVIDIA integrated sustainability principles into product design by improving material efficiency, reducing packaging impacts, and extending product longevity.
The company strengthened oversight of suppliers on environmental, labor, and human-rights expectations, promoting higher sustainability performance across the value chain.
NVIDIA implemented water-efficiency initiatives in manufacturing and data-center environments, including advanced cooling systems that lower operational water use.
The company expanded programs supporting skills development, diversity, and wellbeing across a rapidly growing global workforce.
NVIDIA supported community programs focused on STEM education, disaster relief, and social impact initiatives in the regions where it operates.
The company invested in climate-focused research, including AI for weather modeling, environmental monitoring, and energy-optimization tools.

Tesla highlights that pollution from burning fossil fuels contributes to premature deaths globally each year, and positions its zero direct-emission products as reducing climate-warming carbon and particulate pollution.

The report cites that 1.19 million people die in traffic accidents annually worldwide and states that Tesla's autonomous technologies aim to reduce fatalities by making roads safer for drivers, passengers, and pedestrians.
Tesla asserts that autonomy will save lives, time, and money while improving quality of life by reducing unsafe, repetitive tasks in both homes and workplaces.
Tesla reports that a U.S. Tesla vehicle avoids an average of 52 metric tons of CO2e over its lifetime, noting EV emissions decrease over time as electricity grids become cleaner.
The report states that electrifying heavy-duty trucking with the Tesla Semi is critical to reducing transport emissions and achieving sustainable industrial logistics.
Tesla reports a 99.95% average uptime for Supercharger sites in 2024, enabling reliable long-distance travel and supporting emissions-free mobility.
Tesla reports 6.5 vehicle fires per billion miles driven, positioning its vehicles as significantly safer than the U.S. national average.
The report shows Autopilot technology results in far fewer accidents per million miles driven compared with both driving without Autopilot and the U.S. national average.
Tesla's Megapack and Powerwall systems provided grid-support services globally, including 2.8 GWh of energy delivered through Virtual Power Plants in 2024.
Tesla reports significant battery-recycling achievements, including 1.7 GWh of material processed and 590 metric tons of recovered materials.
Coca-Cola reports replenishing 163% of the water used in its finished beverages globally in 2024, continuing a trend of exceeding 100% replenishment every year since 2015.
Water efficiency across the Coca-Cola system improved 10% in 2024 compared with a 2015 baseline, with a system-wide water-use ratio of 1.78 liters of water per liter of product.
Coca-Cola used 28% recycled material in its global primary consumer packaging in 2024, including 18% recycled PET.
The report states that 99% of Coca-Cola’s primary consumer packaging was recyclable globally in 2024.
In 2024, 14% of Coca-Cola’s total beverage volume was served in reusable packaging, with sales of reusable packaging increasing by 24 million unit cases from 2023.
Coca-Cola collected and refilled or recycled 65% of the equivalent bottles and cans it introduced into the market in 2024.
Coca-Cola system-wide renewable electricity use reached 28% in 2024.
Coca-Cola reported total Scope 1 emissions of 474,413 metric tons of CO2e in 2024, noting that expanded reporting boundaries make year-over-year comparisons not applicable.
In 2024, Coca-Cola reported 812,050 metric tons of CO2e under the market-based method for Scope 2 emissions.
Coca-Cola system franchise manufacturing energy emissions were 4,538,363 metric tons of CO2e (location-based) in 2024.
